title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim credits for wetland restoration, conservation, and easements. The wetland restoration credit is based on expenditures for restoring farmed or converted wetlands to their natural state, approved by the Natural Resources Conservation Service. The wetland conservation credit is based on a restoration plan approved by the Natural Resources Conservation Service and incurred within the first 5 years of a conservation agreement or easement. It includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and certification fees. The wetland conservation credit includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and certification fees based on the term of the conservation agreement. The wetland conservation credit percentage varies based on the number of years of the conservation agreement: 50% for 10-20 years, 60% for 20-30 years, and 70% for 30 years. If the taxpayer elects the wetland easement credit, the conservation credit for that wetland is zero. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The value is determined by a certified appraisal of the wetland in agricultural use during the taxable year. The taxpayer can claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The value is determined by a certified appraisal of the wetland in agricultural use during the taxable year. Eligible taxpayers must own wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands, along with surrounding actively farmed cropland, and have entered into a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The taxpayer can claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. Qualified wetlands include wetlands being converted to fully functioning condition through restoration expenditures, along with surrounding nonwetland areas for water quality or wildlife habitat buffering. The taxpayer can claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, including surrounding nonwetland areas for buffering water quality or wildlife habitat values. Wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland are defined by the Food Security Act of 1985. The Wetlands Reserve Program, as defined by the Food Security Act of 1985, includes terms such as wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland. A qualified conservation agreement involves an eligible taxpayer agreeing to comply with conservation requirements for a specified wetland area for a term of 10 to 30 years. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for the qualified wetland, including not using it for agricultural production and not manipulating it in any way. Certification of compliance is required every 5 years during the agreement term. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for the qualified wetland, including not manipulating it for agricultural production. A qualified conservation easement must be granted in perpetuity to a qualified organization for conservation purposes. No double benefit is allowed for expenses claimed under the subsection. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for the qualified wetland and grant a qualified conservation easement in perpetuity to a qualified organization for conservation purposes. No double benefit is allowed for expenses claimed under the subsection. Married couples must file joint returns for this section to apply. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements and grant a conservation easement in perpetuity to a qualified organization. Married couples must file joint returns for this section to apply. Amendments are made to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998.
